Award.AwardTitle: PFI-TT: Energy-Efficient Smart-Privacy Windows made of Dynamic Crystals
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact and commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project includes the development of inexpensive, energy-efficient window technologies and devices. Optical light transmission of such windows will be switchable by low-voltage electric fields within a fraction of a second. Beyond windows, other potential applications include coverings of greenhouses, skylights, and a large variety of electro-optic applications. The societal outcomes include reduction of energy consumption, improved comfort of building inhabitants, reduced energy demand, and creation of new jobs associated with manufacturing of these new breeds of energy-efficient windows. The team will utilize demonstrations based on the projectâ€™s outcomes to contribute to the general public's appreciation of the importance of the energy efficient technologies.

The proposed project develops energy efficient windows capable of dynamically controlling transmitted light by applying low voltages (~1 Volt). Commercial and residential windows are the source of loss of about 40% of heating/cooling energy. The nanostructured liquid crystal technology promises to improve dynamic windows by controlling light transmission in the visible and near-infrared. This control will be achieved using a thin layer of a liquid crystal with ordered metal nanoparticles dispersed within it, which can be continuously rotated or switched using low-voltage fields. The main goal of this project is to develop and test prototypes of inexpensive. electrically-switchable windows while solving technological hurdles related to the speed of switching and scaling their dimensions. Skylights are the initial target market. The team will explore how these switchable devices can be engineered using nanoparticle-doped liquid crystals for applications in buildings within different climate zones. This application may lay the groundwork for a number of other technologies that rely on electrically-controlled molecular and nanoparticle organization at the mesoscale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This PFI-TT project developed smart-privacy windows capable of dynamically controlling light transmission by voltages ~1V. We have developed the new breed of scalable plasmonic electrochromic windows that allow for fast (~10ms) and uniform electric switching of visible and infrared transparency of windows in both installed glass units and retrofit products. This innovation is poised to allow for combining privacy, energy efficiency and architectural appeal functionalities to save energy and improve comfort of residents. While silver and ITO are commonly used in windows coatings for solar gain control, our patented technology is based on electric switching of orientations of plasmonic silver nanoparticles (nanorods and nanoplates) dispersed in a liquid crystal (LC) by applying ~1V to ITO electrodes. This approach and its outcomes will be transformative compared to passive silver/ITO-based products, enabling dynamic tuning of transparency & solar gain. It is disruptive compared to electrochromic windows & does not suffer from slow nonuniform switching & scaling problems. The PI and the student (Pedro de Melo) developed small prototypes of installed and retrofit smart-privacy window products that are based on electric switching of liquid crystalline (LC) dispersions of anisotropic plasmonic metal nanoparticles, with skylights being the initial target market.  The graduate student with MSE background satisfied the MSE program’s course requirements and will take part in the short courses of CU-Boulder’s Venture Partners Office that focus on customer discovery, startup and IP essentials and so on. The NSF PFI-TT project's program was an essential part of research training and preparation, along with frequent interactions with partners and collaborators at a startup iFeather, the major window industry representatives of Cardinal Glass Industries (CGI) and colleagues at NREL.
